title: ANZ stumps up $150m loan for sold-out Tim Gurner project
text:
Mr Williams said senior bank debt was significantly cheaper than a loan from a non-bank lender and the higher interest payments eroded project profits.

Despite securing $450 million from ANZ in just a few months, Mr Gurner backed the role of non-bank lenders in the market.

"I think it’s fantastic that groups like MaxCap (which helped fund his FV project in Brisbane) have come into the senior lending market and really shaken up the industry, taking a huge chunk of the banks’ lending books.

"It is critical that in any market there is competition to ensure everyone is kept honest on fees and structures.

"The non-bank sector of the construction loan market is now a very large percentage of all deals and I believe this will continue to grow until the banks decide they have lost too much market share and start to compete harder again.

The sell-out of Mr Gurner's Victoria and Vine project comes as the Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle warned that a shortfall of housing was quite likely in the foreseeable future.

“There is no question sentiment continues to have a huge effect on the investment market, however sophisticated investors are now seeing the huge drop-off in rental apartment supply as demand continues to rise, pushing vacancy rates to near critical levels, "Mr Gurner said.

"This has encouraged some investors back into the market but there’s no doubt owner occupiers have dominated sales in the last 12 months."

Advertisement

Bordered by Victoria Parade, Cambridge, Derby and Wellington streets, the 5000 square metre project across a suburban block with 200 metres of frontage features 241 apartments, of which 236 have been sold.

He acquired the site in 2016 in a $40 million deal with the local private owners.

Sales included a $7.5 million penthouse, which Mr Gurner claimed was a suburb record, and another penthouse sold for $6.75 million.

Another 25 three bedroom apartments sold for between $1.5 million and $5.7 million.

"Our buyers have been a mix of downsizers, upsizers, families, couples, first home buyers and investors," Mr Gurner said.

Prefab building specialist Hickory has been appointed to construct the project, which will kick off this month, well ahead of its mid to late 2020 planned start.
description: Rich Lister Tim Gurner has secured $450 million in funding from ANZ in just three months for two projects, but says non-banks also have a role to play.
